channel.title: Projects on Ross A. Baker
channel.description: Recent content in Projects on Ross A. Baker

item.title: Finger me
item.description: Long ago, I stumbled across HyperTerminal on the family Windows 95 machine. I figured out how to dial into my mom-and-pop ISP with that, and had my first shell access on a multi-user machine. Magical. A friendly admin taught me a lot, including how to make a .plan on one of the great social networks of the day, Finger. I can be fingered once again on Happy Net Box. Run this from your own shell:

item.title: Scalatra in Action
item.description: Scalatra in Action was written by Dave Hrycyszyn, Stefan Ollinger, and me and covers the Scalatra micro-framework in depth. Scalatra is a port of Ruby’s Sinatra to Scala.

item.title: Archive your toots to Hugo
item.description: An important Indieweb principle is to own your data. I tooted on mastodon.social sporadically for five years. The service is public, the protocol open, and the implementation open source. Still, it exists at the pleasure of its admins, with whom I have no contract. After moving to another instance, I wanted to preserve my old content. We will use a technique called PESOS, or Publish Elsewhere, Syndicate to Own Site.

item.title: Personal Weather Station
item.description: I run an Ambient Weather WS-1400-IP weather station in the Castleton neighborhood of Indianapolis and share its public dashboard. The anemometer is not raised high enough for accuracy, but the rest is reasonably accurate. I learned on 2022-09-06 that the Indianapolis Metropolitan Airport is now publishing METAR data. That airport is just a mile away, and certainly has a more credible weather station, but it’s fun to compare to mine.
